prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN vib excited - T Tauri stars
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setting containing the HCN vib excited line (main goal of project) together with HCN v=0 isotopolog lines. Two T Tauri disks are targeted in this Science goal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main goal of the project is the vibrationally excited HCN v2=1 J=4-3 line at 356.256 GHz. Since the line is broad, a moderate spectral resolution is chosen and the data will be binned to 2.5 km/s km/s (or more if the line is weak). The spectral setting also includes 3 basebands centered on the HCN, H13CN and HC15N v=0 J=4-3 lines which should be readily detectable and which originate from the outer disk. The isotopologues are needed to constrain the optical depth of HCN v=0 itself. Since the S/N is expected to be high on these lines, especially for the main HCN isotopologue, a high spectral resolution is chosen to reveal the full kinematics of the lines in the slower rotating outer disk. The spectral sampling is then chosen so as to stay within the 12 Mb/s data rate. Binning to lower spectral resolution (about 0.5 km/s) of the HCN v=0 isotopologue lines can be done to boost S/N if needed.

The proposed configuration is C36-4 to obtain a spatial resolution of ~0.2" (~15 au radius at the 125 pc distance of the sources), but the precise configuration is not critical since the vibrationally excited HCN lines will remain spatially unresolved; any configuration that gives an angualr resolution between 0.14" and 0.3" is acceptable. This will allow us to link the inner disk HCN abundance to that in the outer disk on scales of 10s of au.
The largest angular scale is set by the size of the disk as probed in the HCN v=0 line. In the proposed configuration, the bulk of the full disk emission will be recovered even for large disks such as HD 163296. The outermost part of the disk is not the focus of this study.

The expected line emission for the vibrationally excited HCN line has been computed using 2D models for these disks with the DALI code of Bruderer et al. (2012, 2013). Model results for AS 205N are presented in Figure 3, with peak line fluxes ranging from 5-10 mJy for different assumptions about the HCN abundance (Figure 3). Since the lines are broad, we can bin the spectra and use a bandwidth of 2.5 km/s for setting the rms and S/N. The requested 1sigma sensitivity is 1.1 mJy in the C36-4 configuration in the second quartile weather. This will ensure a 3sigma detection of the line profile for the more pessimistic flux estimate. The line/continuum ratio is larger than 0.01 so there is no dynamic range issue (Bruderer et al. 2015).
The v=0 HCN, H13CN and HC15N J=4-3 lines should be readily detected at 0.4 km/s: disk integrated fluxes for the HCN v=0 J=3-2 line observed with the SMA range from 200-900 mJy km/s for a large sample of disks including some proposed here (Oberg et al. 2011). The J=4-3 fluxes should be similar, and the H13CN and HC15N lines are expected to be factors of 5-50 times lower (the H12CN line is optically thick). HCN peak fluxes are above 400 mJy per 0.4 km/s bins so self-calibration with this line should be possible.
The basis for the simulations in Figure 3 is a physical structure constrained by modeling simultaneously the SED and continuum images using a parametrized surface density profile as given in Andrews et al. 2009. Grain growth and settling is taken into account through a parametrization. The total gas mass can be independently determined from observations of CO isotopologs as demonstrated by Miotello et al. (2014), including the effects of isotope selective photodissociation. Such data already exist for HD 163296 and are requested here for AS 205N and RNO90 at 0.2" resolution (Science Goal 3).
In the inner disk, a substantial fraction of dust may be locked up in large boulders, so the gas/(small) dust ratio may be significantly larger than 100 (models in Figure 3 use g/d=1000 and 0.99 in large grains). The abundance structure is taken to be either constant or to have a jump with a higher abundance in the hot FUV shielded inner disk above a temperature T_jump. The models include both thermal and turbulent broadening (FWHM=0.1 km/s) as well as full continuum and line radiative transfer using the new non-LTE model of Bruderer et al. (2015), which takes collisional excitation and radiative pumping into account. This allows modeling of both the mid-infrared lines as well as the ALMA lines with the same model. The lines are ray-traced to obtain the emitting profiles. Best fit values of x_in and x_out can then be obtained within the context of the adopted physical model.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN vib excited - Herbig star
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setting containing the HCN vib excited line (main goal of project) together with HCN v=0 isotopolog lines. This science goal targets 1 Herbig disks

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main goal of the project is the vibrationally excited HCN v2=1 J=4-3 line at 356.256 GHz. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO and C18O 3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO isotopologues for the 2 T Tauri disks

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since the S/N is expected to be high, especially for 13CO, a high spectral resolution is chosen to reveal the full disk kinematics for comparison with high S/N HCN v=0 lines. Spectral binning can be done if the lines turn out to be weaker than expected. CN is added in the upper sideband and provides serendipitous information on the CN/HCN ratio in the outer disk, which in turn provides useful information on the amount of FUV radiation from these T Tauri stars since CN is a photodissociation product of HCN.

The proposed configuration of C36-4 is set bij the HCN requirements and gives a sparial resolution of ~0.2" (~15 au radius at the 125 pc distance of the sources). As for HCN, the precise configuration is not critical as long as the gas surface density structure can be reconstructed on scales of 10s of au. This structure is then extrapolated to the inner disk based on the inferred power-law density structure and used for HCN abundance determination.
The largest angular scale is set by the size of the disk as probed in 13CO or HCN v=0 ines. In the proposed configuration, the bulk of the full disk emission will be recovered. The outer disk is not the focus of this study.

The 13CO and C18O 3-2 lines are obtained to constrain the gas surface density structure at 0.2" resolution for the two disks for which such data do not exist. Typical peak fluxes are 200 mJy/beam for 13CO 3-2 and a factor of about 5-10 lower for C18O 3-2, depending on optical depth of the lines (Salyk et al. 2014, Miotello et al. 2014). The lines should be detectable with high S/N for 13CO 3-2 and S/N of at least 3sigma for C18O 3-2 at a nominal spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s. If the disks turn out to have low mass (<10-3 Msun), further binning can be done and/or only 13CO will be used.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Studies of the inner few au of disks - the terrestrial planet forming zone and the realm of the bulk of the detected Jovian exoplanets - have so far been limited to infrared observations. The IR data only probe the surface layers of disks; ALMA provides the first opportunity to probe deeper and closer to the midplane. We propose here a pilot project to use the HCN vibrationally excited J=4-3 line to uniquely probe the physics and chemistry of the inner disk with ALMA for the first time. Due to high temperatures and ice evaporation, abundances are predicted to be orders of magnitude higher in the inner few au, and the vibrationally excited HCN lines have excitation requirements that are beautifully matched to the inner disk physical conditions yet greatly lessen the impact of dust opacity.Combined with HCN v=0 data of the outer disk obtained in the same setting, our data will allow radial and vertical abundance profiles to be retrieved and assess the gas-phase nitrogen budget.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
Center for Astronomy, Heidelberg, University of
